mechanoreception.notes: As sponges, Suberitidae likely possess a basic ability to detect water currents and physical disturbances via mechanoreceptors at the cellular level. This is crucial for filter feeding and other basic functions.

chemoreception.notes: Sponges rely on chemoreception to detect food particles and other chemical cues in the water. This is essential for triggering filter-feeding and other physiological responses.

photoreception.notes: It is unknown whether Suberitidae possess photoreceptors. While sponges generally lack complex nervous systems and eyes, some species may have light-sensitive cells.
